author: jgm
content:
Here are some numbers I ran ~12 hours ago regarding number of proposals by genesis validators:
```
   f_proposed | f_count
  ------------+---------
            0 |    4279
            1 |    6804
            2 |    5418
            3 |    2903
            4 |    1159
            5 |     358
            6 |     107
            7 |      31
            8 |       6
```
so if you haven't proposed yet you aren't alone.

**vbuterin**
Yep, that looks like a poisson distribution with mean 42k/24k to me!

author: potuz
content: <@!144468805697929216> I just realized that my data is not taking into account missed slots, I see a much larger density of missed slots at boundary transitions, are you counting them in yours?

author: ajsutton
content: Would be interesting to know how many of the delayed blocks at slot 1 where after a missed block  0.

author: jgm
content: I'm just taking in notification of the head event from clients.  I _think_ that this means that prysm won't send anything for a missed slot, and teku will but only after a certain time (4s?).

author: ajsutton
content: Yep, Teku will send a head event 4 seconds into the slot with the same block root as the previous slot if no block is received.  We'll drop that at some point in the future when the validator client has switched over to the newer way of detecting reorgs.  It just all landed too close to genesis to switch over.

author: djrtwo
content: So <@!144468805697929216>, the prysm node here can still experience the problem but is *much* more likely to get the new head between 0 and 4s than the teku data shows

content: (note too far beyond 12s is likely to be orphaned. it's really the 4s to 12s delivery range that can show this issue)

author: jgm
content: I think that the problem we're looking it remains the fact that block delays for slot 0 are too high, which then leads to the knock-on effect of more blocks arriving at nodes after the 4 second "start attesting" mark, which leads to more of those blocks being orphaned.  At this stage I'd be tempted to kick it to the client teams to provide some numbers for when they are ready to serve data for each slot, and when they have completed processing for each block (time in to slot, rather than "how fast did you process this block").  That should allow us to work out if this was a network or processing problem.

author: arnetheduck
content: I think generally, the benchmarks lie a bit when they say "processed block in 100ms" - ie they include perhaps the state transition time, but not the _end-to-end_ time

author: potuz
content: <@476250636548308992> can confirm this, but the way I'm getting this data is by getting the stream of blocks as they arrive from the node and then getting the timestamp from the log event after it's been processed. Perhaps measuring the time delta between these two could be a quick benchmark on processing the block

author: arnetheduck
content: so whenever something comes in on the gossip network, it'll go decryption (noise), deserialization (ssz - heavy because deserializing signatures is expensive), usually some form of internal queueing (because client has to serve many peers), gossip validation (filters out the worst cases, includes signature check), state transition itself, then epoch pruning, epoch finalization pruning, validator balance caching  and a bunch of other things, before finally being considered processed

author: jgm
content: Bear in mind we are _not_ after the pure block processing time, but the time between the start of the slot and the end of the block processing process.  Because that's the time that can be impacted by internal epoch processing, late arriving blocks from external sources, _etc_.

author: arnetheduck
content: then it goes through the same thing in reverse, but amplified by the fanout of the client: we have to re-encrypt the block for every client because of the unique session key etc so the _first_ neighbour will receive the block significantly earlier than the last

author: jgm
content: This is true, but hopefully the flow in the client is such that as soon as it has finished processing a block it lets the validator clients know that it is done so, and they can start attesting.

author: nishant0
content: we have a block arrival metric which we do use to calculate the difference between expected time and 'arrival' time. And then group the results into buckets, although not sure how helpful it is to your cause

author: nishant0
content:
my suspicion is that maybe clients are taking a bit longer over here
```
[REJECT] The block is proposed by the expected proposer_index for the block's slot in the context of the current shuffling (defined by parent_root/slot). If the proposer_index cannot immediately be verified against the expected shuffling, the block MAY be queued for
```

author: arnetheduck
content: indeed, we have something similar that tracks that difference, it's actually pretty fun to watch

author: arnetheduck
content: This is a pyrmont node - we can see most blocks for example arriving on time, while attestations are randomly spread around their expected +4s (meaning a significant amount of clients have implemented the randomness fix), then aggregates arriving with some delay

author: arnetheduck
content: nimbus for example starts attesting as soon as it receives the expected block

author: jgm
content: Yeah, that sounds very possible.  I have a similar problem with Vouch sending attestations to multiple clients; some of them haven't seen the relevant block yet, so rejects the attestation.  If an epoch transition hasn't completed then the block will be rejected.

author: arnetheduck
content: then in that graph, just before 11,  we can see how nimbus got blocked for a bit by some processing on the server (a log rotation probably)

author: arnetheduck
content: not sure - we do this one fairly quickly on a hot cache (ie when there's no reorg) - it's an epoch transition away usually from the head

author: nishant0
content: Interesting, do you have more data on which clients rejected it ?

author: nishant0
content: Ah k, so proposer indexes are precomputed then ?

author: jgm
content: Lighthouse does, I *think* teku does as well but can't remember.  It is, of course, an intermittent issue.  And to be fair, rejecting it is (kind-of) the correct thing to do.  Not sure what prysm does in that situation (receiving an attestation with an unknown head)...

author: arnetheduck
content: "almost" - we can't quite compute them, but we make sure to do _only_ the epoch processing to advance to the new epoch slot without the block applied

author: arnetheduck
content: that's something else - when working with the first slot in the epoch we always do so without the block applied - that ensures we have a clean slate in case the first block is orphaned - for example when storing the epoch state in the database for slot 32, it's stored without the block at slot 32 applied

author: arnetheduck
content: same thing for the epoch cache - it's produced without the block, because the block doesn't really matter for the shuffling and fork choice in that epoch

author: ajsutton
content: So most of yesterday AU time, we had half the fix running on all our Pyrmont boxes - deployed the wrong build for testing.  Even with both epoch optimisation PRs merged, I don't see a major reduction in CPU usage on Pyrmont.  The old code wasn't as unoptimised as it first looked because of the caching Teku does - the new version is definitely better and not running epoch multiple times is a bigger win but it's not a game changer.  I'm going to keep digging today, current theory is that it's the storage system causing delays.

author: ajsutton
content: <@!755590043632140352> btw the graffiti on the boxes with the fix will include 20.11.1+52-gf055da7 Should be the last 3856 or so of our validators.

What I am trying to check is if these improvements in epoch transition help or not in the block delay. I'll comare Teku with fixes to Teku with baseline, before the fixes. So if I'm not including a large quantity of Teku nodes with fixes then this test will be useless

author: ajsutton
content: Yep, will keep those two boxes stable for a while. Can always deploy other fixes to some of our other pyrmont nodes to compare.
